About 6 million tons of construction and demolition debris are generated in New York City every year.

This amounts to 46% of all waste generated in the city—almost the same quantity by weight as generated by residents as businesses combined.*OneNYC, 2014; NYSDEC C&D Processors and Transfer Stations Annual Reports, 2015; New York City Commercial Solid Waste Study and Analysis, 2012 Summary Report.

Scroll down to begin

Swipe right to begin

GENERATION

Debris and fill

Construction and demolition (C&D) debris is generated by new constructions, renovations, land clearing, excavations, and demolitions. This includes work on buildings, roads, and utilities.

This type of waste is usually divided into two main categories: excavated earth, concrete, and stones (also called fill material); and another category for all other debris.

COLLECTION

Contractors and haulers

On the job-site, contractors collect debris in containers, which are rented by private C&D haulers. These containers vary widely in size, ranging in length from 1 to 20 yards.

As with other types of commercial waste, this part of the waste system is entirely private and thus not collected by DSNY.

Source separation

Some contractors will separate the debris into a series of materials, including metal, wood, masonry, and cardboard. In other cases, haulers will collect everything commingled, and materials may or may not be separate at a processing facility.

The capacity for source separation depends on a series of factors, including space constraints for different containers on the job-site; financial incentives from haulers; and job-site scheduling.

The "mini" container

The yard-long, "mini" container is commonly used in job-sites in New York City, usually due to space constraints.

Here, we see containers source-separated for metals, a material with high recycling value, being collected by a private hauler.

The rear-loader trucks usually have cables or mechanical arms that lift and tip the containers.

To a processing facility or transfer station

When collection trucks are full, they head to a C&D debris processing facility or to a transfer station. The main difference between the two is that processing facilities will try to recover certain materials from the debris for recycling or for use as landfill cover, while materials arriving at a transfer station almost always end up in landfills or incinerators.

Haulers in New York City can use one of the more than 40 processing facilities located in the city, as well as many other facilities in Long Island, Upstate New York, or New Jersey.

(Click map to replay animation. The data displays on the map only includes facilities within New York City)

PROCESSING

Arriving at a processing facility

C&D debris processing facilities are similar in many ways to waste transfer stations. They are primarily logistical centers for debris, consolidating loads from smaller trucks into bigger ones before sending it outside of the city.

Because C&D facilities handle materials different from the ones received at transfer stations, they are subject to different regulations by the State's Department of Environmental Conservation. One of the regulations is to control dust, and in order to comply with this many facilities will hose the debris with water.

Separating materials

Inside the facility, workers will direct drivers on where to unload the debris. The main objective is to keep different materials separated, so that recyclables can be recovered and sold.

Materials that can be used as landfill cover are also separated, such as excavated earth, concrete and stones, known as fill material.

RECYCLING

How much is recycled?

Rates are hard to estimate; is alternate daily cover actual recycling?

LANDFILLING

Sending it "away"

Materials that are not recovered for recycling are either sent to landfills or to other C&D processors, for further separation.

(Click map to replay animation)

But this is just a part of the story.

As part of its commitment to become a zero waste city by 2030, New York is seeking to reduce commercial waste disposal by 90 percent.

To do so, the City is considering adopting a waste franchising system; encouraging large commercial buildings to recycle more through audits and a Zero Waste Challenge program; revising and simplifying recycling rules for businesses; and requiring all food service establishments to separate food waste for composting.

But this is just a part of the story.

As part of its commitment to become a zero waste city by 2030, New York is seeking to reduce commercial waste disposal by 90 percent.

 

To do so, the City is considering adopting a waste franchising system; encouraging large commercial buildings to recycle more through audits and a Zero Waste Challenge program; revising and simplifying recycling rules for businesses; and requiring all food service establishments to separate food waste for composting.

 

Addressing commercial waste is particularly important in planning for a zero waste New York, since it accounts for about 27% of all waste generated in the city.
